subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Let me introduce myself...
msgSnippet: ... From: Benct Philip Jonsson To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com Sent: Thursday, January 06, 2005 4:23 PM Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Let me introduce myself...
messageBody:
----- Original Message -----
From: Benct Philip Jonsson
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, January 06, 2005 4:23 PM
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Let me introduce myself...


Hello everybody,

My name is Benct Philip Jonsson, and I live in Gothenburg,
Sweden.  I have a general interest in things linguistic and some
semesters of training in Scandinavian and Indo-European
philology.  There is a special place in my heart for writing
systems, and thence for transliteration, spelling reform and the
development of writing systems for hitherto unwritten languages.
I'm also a shorthand user since almost twenty years (Melin's
Swedish system, which I have adapted myself to English and
Icelandic).  I have known of Shavian for almost as long as I've
been interested in Shorthand, but learnt of Quikscript only
recently (at omniglot.com).

I have two questions:

What is the logic behind the Quiqscript font layout?
 
Welcome Benct:
 
I assume the preceding question is referring to the keyboard layout.  The standard keyboard layout is based upon the layout which was in use on the Shavian site when this site was started.  I did not find it particularly appealing or intuitive for QS although one can get used to it.  I believe part of the "logic" used is based on some of the symbols used by the International Phonetic Alphabet.  This is fine if you happen to know the IPA, but it is my contention that if we want to reach the general population of English writers who were taught traditional orthography (T.O.) in school, the IPA is no help because the general public knows little or nothing about it.  It makes more sense to me to use a system that has some relation to T.O. which English readers and writers do know about.
 
Therefore, several people worked together to come up with an alternate keyboard mapping which seems more intuitive to me than what the Shavian group is using.  This requires the use of the program "Keyman."  One advantage which Keyman permits is that the numerous English vowels, which are now represented in T.O. by two vowels placed together, can be mapped to the appropriate QS symbol by typing the two vowels one after the other.  I find this easier to remember than altering the keyboard vowel letter by using the shift key, and it may be faster too since you don't have to move your little fingers to the shift key.  If you find none of the alternatives on the website appealing, Keyman permits you to put together you own keymapping that works for you if you choose to.  Some people may argue that we need to agree on a standard mapping, and in the long run that may be true.  At this time, however, I'm unlikely to run into QS on someone else's computer, and I don't think that is likely to change any time soon.  
 
Spread the word about QS to your friends who are interested in a more efficient way to write in English.
 
Paige Gabhart
 

Do speakers of American accents with merger between the vowels
of father-cot-caught spell accordingly?  And if so, which letter
do they use?
 
I consistently distinguish between the vowels you are asking about, but would expect that a person whose idiolect has merged these vowels would use only the short "o" ["on" in Shavian] sound to symbolize all three when writing in QS. 
 
 
Paige Gabhart


--

/BP 8^)>
--
Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch at melroch dot se

         Solitudinem faciunt pacem appellant!
                                             (Tacitus)
